misconceptions.name: No random number or game state generated
misconceptions.description: The program does not generate or store a random target number between 1 and 100, so there is no game state for the user to guess.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving this problem involves computing the cost of a road trip rather than setting up a random number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should create a Random object, generate an int between 1 and 100, and store it in a variable (e.g., int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1) for the user to guess.
symptoms: No Random object is created
No integer variable represents the secret number
Program logic is entirely about driving distance and fuel cost
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment requirements or reuse of code from a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the road trip cost logic with code that creates a Random instance, generates an int from 1 to 100, and stores it in a variable that will be compared against user guesses.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is for a different problem and contains no random number generation or game state.

evidence.note: The program never creates a Random object or an int answer variable; instead it focuses on road trip cost calculation.

misconceptions.name: No loop to allow multiple guesses
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any loop to allow the user to repeatedly guess until they get the correct number.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to think that a single-pass calculation program (no repetition) is sufficient for the task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The guessing game should use a loop (while or do-while) that repeatedly prompts for guesses until the user guesses the secret number.
symptoms: Only one linear sequence of input prompts
No while or do-while loop
No mechanism to repeat interaction based on correctness of a guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding that the problem requires an interactive repeated-guess game rather than a one-time computation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a while or do-while loop that continues prompting for a guess and comparing it to the secret number until the guess is correct.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no loop constructs at all; only straight-line input/output for a different problem.

evidence.note: There are no while/do-while or for loops; the program runs once from top to bottom and exits.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to report guesses that are too high
misconceptions.description: The program never compares a user guess to a target number or prints a "Too high" message when appropriate.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears unaware that they must compare guesses to a secret number and give directional feedback.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The code should compare the user's numeric guess with the secret number and, if the guess is greater, print "Too high!".
symptoms: No integer guess variable
No comparison using > between guess and secret
No output containing the phrase "Too high" or equivalent
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a different computational problem with no comparison-based feedback.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a guess, add an if statement that checks if guess > answer and prints "Too high!" in that case.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code never reads a guess or prints any conditional message related to its size; it's all about cost calculation.

evidence.note: Inputs and outputs are about distance, mpg, and price; there is no guess variable or "Too high" message.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to report guesses that are too low
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any logic to detect when a guess is lower than the secret number and respond with a "Too low" hint.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems not to implement any of the guessing feedback behavior, including handling guesses that are too low.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should compare the user's guess to the secret number, and if the guess is smaller, print "Too low!".
symptoms: No integer guess value
No comparison using < between guess and secret
No output containing "Too low" or similar wording
misconceptions.root_cause: Student wrote a different application that does not rely on comparative feedback.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each guess, add an else-if branch that checks if guess < answer and prints "Too low!".
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No guessing or comparison logic appears anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: The only decision-related construct is the ternary with hasNextDouble; there is no branching based on a guess being too low.

misconceptions.name: No termination condition based on a correct guess
misconceptions.description: The program never checks for a correct guess or counts the number of guesses, so it cannot terminate the game with a summary when the user guesses correctly.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student treats the program as a single computation that ends after one calculation instead of a game that ends when the correct guess is made.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The loop should continue until the user's guess equals the secret number, at which point the program prints a success message including the number of attempts and then terminates.
symptoms: No equality check between a guess and a secret number
No counter for number of guesses
Program terminates after computing and printing driving cost
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment as a straightforward numeric calculation task rather than a stateful interactive loop.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int guesses counter and a condition in the loop that checks if guess == answer; when true, print a "Correct!" message with the guess count and exit the loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no variable for number of guesses or equality check; the program ends after one calculation.

evidence.note: Program control flow goes directly from computing cost to printing and closing input; there is no loop or condition based on a correct guess.

Input prompts ask for distance, MPG, and price

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of the number guessing game specified in Q2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the assignment or submitted code from a different problem entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1-100 and the user guesses until correct, with 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback provided after each wrong guess.
symptoms: Code implements road trip cost calculation logic
No random number generation for guessing game
No loop for multiple guesses
No comparison logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback
Program logic is entirely unrelated to the assignment
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted incorrect code - either copied from a different assignment, submitted the wrong file, or misunderstood the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q2 problem specification carefully. Implement a guessing game using Random to generate a number, a loop to allow multiple guesses, and conditional statements to provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a road trip cost problem, not a number guessing game. The problem statement and code are completely mismatched.

evidence.note: This is a road trip cost calculator, not a number guessing game. The entire program logic is wrong for the assignment.

misconceptions.name: No random number generation or game state
misconceptions.description: The program does not generate a random number between 1 and 100 or maintain any game state; instead it solves a different problem (road trip cost).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading numeric input for a cost calculation is sufficient for this task, without needing to generate or use a random secret number.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use a Random object (e.g., rand.nextInt(100) + 1) to generate a secret number between 1 and 100 and store it so guesses can be checked against it.
symptoms: No Random object is declared or used
No variable represents a secret target number for the game
Program logic is entirely about distance, mpg, and fuel price
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem requirements or lack of understanding of how to set up a random-based guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce `Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;` at the start of main and store `answer` as the secret number used for comparisons.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code never uses Random and implements a completely different program focused on driving cost.

evidence.note: Shows program setup and inputs for a cost calculation, with no Random usage or secret number.

misconceptions.name: Missing guessing loop
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any loop to allow repeated guesses; it performs a one-time cost computation and exits.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a single sequence of inputs and one final output is sufficient, without needing a loop to repeat guesses until correct.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use a loop (while or do-while) to repeatedly prompt the user for guesses and only terminate when the correct number is guessed.
symptoms: No while or do-while loops in the code
User is never asked to guess a number multiple times
Program ends after computing and printing driving cost
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the task as a single-step calculation rather than an interactive guessing game requiring repetition.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the input and comparison of the user's guess in a while loop that continues until the guess equals the secret number, counting attempts.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop structure; the code is linear and unrelated to repeated guessing.

evidence.note: Entire main method is a straight-line computation; no loop appears to support multiple guesses.

misconceptions.name: No comparison or 'Too high' feedback
misconceptions.description: The program never compares a guess against a secret number and never prints a 'Too high' message to guide the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe no high/low feedback is needed, since they are not implementing a guessing game at all.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After each incorrect guess that is greater than the secret number, the program should print a 'Too high!' hint to help the user adjust their next guess.
symptoms: No variable for a guess or for a secret number
No conditional branches testing guess > answer
No output string containing 'Too high'
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to implement the comparison logic necessary for a number guessing game and misunderstanding of the required interactive feedback.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a guess, use an if-statement: if (guess > answer) { System.out.println("Too high!"); } in the guessing loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no guess/answer comparison or 'Too high' message of any form.

evidence.note: Final output is a cost statement; no conditional messages like 'Too high' are printed anywhere in the program.

misconceptions.name: No comparison or 'Too low' feedback
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any logic to detect guesses that are too low or to print a 'Too low' hint.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe detailed feedback on guesses is unnecessary, focusing only on a single cost calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a guess is less than the secret number, the program should respond with 'Too low!' so the user knows to guess higher.
symptoms: No representation of a guess or target answer
No conditional branch testing guess < answer
No output string containing 'Too low'
misconceptions.root_cause: Not implementing the core game mechanic of comparing guesses to a target number and providing directional feedback.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: In the guessing loop, add an else-if branch: else if (guess < answer) { System.out.println("Too low!"); }.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no guess-related conditionals or any 'Too low' string.

evidence.note: Inputs are for distance, mpg, and price only; no guesses or 'Too low' feedback are present.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect termination condition for game
misconceptions.description: The program terminates after computing and printing driving cost, not based on the user making a correct guess.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the program should end immediately after performing a single calculation, without any notion of a 'correct guess' condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The loop should continue until the user guesses the secret number correctly, and then the program should report success and the number of guesses before terminating.
symptoms: Program ends after printing cost, regardless of any user guessing
No equality check like guess == answer to control termination
No message indicating the number of guesses or that the guess was correct
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding that the game must end when a logical condition (correct guess) is met, not just when input is exhausted or a single computation is done.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Control the loop with a condition like `while (guess != answer)` and, once the user guesses correctly, print a 'Correct!' message and the guess count before exiting.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no concept of a guess or correctness in the program; termination is just end-of-main.

evidence.note: Program exits after printing cost and closing the scanner; there is no termination logic tied to a correct guess.
